citations.narrative:
Primary enclosure failed to protect a bird from injury.
***Per the medical record, on November 28th, 2023 a 4 year old male Barred owl was located on the ground with his leg
caught up under the barrier between his mew and the mew of his neighbor, a 7 year old male Red-tailed hawk. The Red-
tailed hawk had a hold of the Barred owl’s right leg. The Barred owl was removed from the primary enclosure and
transferred to the veterinary clinic where he received medical attention. The right leg contained an extensive degloving
injury that lead to the election of humane euthanasia. Birds that are housed in enclosures in disrepair may suffer from
stress, injury, or death. Correct by 1/19/2024 by ensuring that bird enclosures are maintained in good repair, protect the
birds from injury, contain the birds, and restrict other animals from entering which may negatively affect the welfare of the
birds within. Corrected at the time of inspection.

Per medical record, one female black-capped squired monkey was found deceased on May 22nd, 2023 and another on
May 26th, 2023. On both of the necropsy reports, it indicates that the findings are consistent with acute systemic
toxoplasmosis. In the report it also indicates that this disease is most likely associated with environmental contamination.
When housing facilities are contaminated and not properly cleaned and sanitized, animals housed within can become sick
and potentially die. Correct by 1/19/2024 by ensuring that these facilities are cleaned and sanitized in a manor that
prevents the potential for disease hazards.

During the inspection, a night house that allows indoor access to two female river otters was found to have insufficient
heating or cooling. When indoor facilities do not have the ability to regulate proper heating or cooling, it cannot protect
animals from extreme temperatures and can cause illness and death. Correct by 1/19/2024 by ensuring that the ambient
temperatures shall not be allowed to fall below nor rise above temperatures compatible with the health or comfort of the
animal.

Multiple enclosures located throughout the entire property contained a moderate amount of clutter, trash, and debris.
When asked about the findings, staff members explained that it was due to them been short staffed. When there is not a
sufficient number of adequately trained employees, animal welfare can be negatively impacted. Correct by 2/2/2024 by
obtaining an adequate number of adequately trained employees that can maintain a professional acceptable level of
husbandry practices set forth in this subpart.

At the time of inspection, a male pygmy hippo was observed demonstrating a hindlimb lameness. When the caretaker
was asked about his condition, she explained that they had observed aggression from the potentially pregnant female
hippo housed in the same primary enclosure. This display of aggression was not a new finding and the hippos were not
separated. Animals housed in the same primary enclosure must be compatible or can result in injury, stress, and death.
Correct by 1/19/2024 by ensuring that animals are housed with animals that do not interfere with their health or cause
them discomfort.

Per the assistant care taker manager, on June 19th, 2023 a flighted 20 year old female Grey Parrot was being transported
across the services parking lot from the vet clinic clutched to her chest without transport container. The bird escaped the
care takers hands and flew off zoo grounds and into a near by tree. Attempts were made to encourage the bird down out
of the tree, but she flew back across the boulevard where visualizations were lost and the bird was not recovered.
Animals that are not handled in a manor that keeps them contained can lead to escapes, physical harm and undue stress.
Correct by 1/19/2024 by ensuring that animals are handlined in a manor that prevents an escape.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
TANESHA WILKINS n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
Primary enclosure failed to protect a bird from injury.  
 
***Per the medical record, on November 28th, 2023 a 4 year old male Barred owl was located on the ground with his leg 
caught up under the barrier between his mew and the mew of his neighbor, a 7 year old male Red-tailed hawk. The Red-
tailed hawk had a hold of the Barred owl’s right leg. The Barred owl was removed from the primary enclosure and 
transferred to the veterinary clinic where he received medical attention. The right leg contained an extensive degloving 
injury that lead to the election of humane euthanasia. Birds that are housed in enclosures in disrepair may suffer from 
stress, injury, or death. Correct by 1/19/2024 by ensuring that bird enclosures are maintained in good repair, protect the 
birds from injury, contain the birds, and restrict other animals from entering which may negatively affect the welfare of the 
birds within. Corrected at the time of inspection. 
3.75(c)(3)  Critical
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Per medical record, one female black-capped squired monkey was found deceased on May 22nd, 2023 and another on 
May 26th, 2023. On both of the necropsy reports, it indicates that the findings are consistent with acute systemic 
toxoplasmosis. In the report it also indicates that this disease is most likely associated with environmental contamination. 
When housing facilities are contaminated and not properly cleaned and sanitized, animals housed within can become sick 
and potentially die. Correct by 1/19/2024 by ensuring that these facilities are cleaned and sanitized in a manor that 
prevents the potential for disease hazards. 
3.126(a) 
   
Facilities, indoor. 
During the inspection, a night house that allows indoor access to two female river otters was found to have insufficient 
heating or cooling. When indoor facilities do not have the ability to regulate proper heating or cooling, it cannot protect 
animals from extreme temperatures and can cause illness and death. Correct by 1/19/2024 by ensuring that the ambient 
temperatures shall not be allowed to fall below nor rise above temperatures compatible with the health or comfort of the 
animal.

3.132 
   
Employees. 
Multiple enclosures located throughout the entire property contained a moderate amount of clutter, trash, and debris. 
When asked about the findings, staff members explained that it was due to them been short staffed. When there is not a 
sufficient number of adequately trained employees, animal welfare can be negatively impacted. Correct by 2/2/2024 by 
obtaining an adequate number of adequately trained employees that can maintain a professional acceptable level of 
husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. 
3.133  Critical
   
Separation. 
At the time of inspection, a male pygmy hippo was observed demonstrating a hindlimb lameness. When the caretaker 
was asked about his condition, she explained that they had observed aggression from the potentially pregnant female 
hippo housed in the same primary enclosure. This display of aggression was not a new finding and the hippos were not 
separated. Animals housed in the same primary enclosure must be compatible or can result in injury, stress, and death. 
Correct by 1/19/2024 by ensuring that animals are housed with animals that do not interfere with their health or cause 
them discomfort. 
3.167(b)  Critical
   
Handling 
Per the assistant care taker manager, on June 19th, 2023 a flighted 20 year old female Grey Parrot was being transported 
across the services parking lot from the vet clinic clutched to her chest without transport container. The bird escaped the 
care takers hands and flew off zoo grounds and into a near by tree. Attempts were made to encourage the bird down out 
of the tree, but she flew back across the boulevard where visualizations were lost and the bird was not recovered. 
Animals that are not handled in a manor that keeps them contained can lead to escapes, physical harm and undue stress. 
Correct by 1/19/2024 by ensuring that animals are handlined in a manor that prevents an escape. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
TANESHA WILKINS n
